paper_abstract: The complexity of finding -approximate first-order critical points for the general smooth constrained optimization problem is shown to be no worse that in terms of function and constraints evaluations. This result is obtained by analyzing the worst-case behaviour of a first-order short-step homotopy algorithm consisting of a feasibility phase followed by an optimization phase, and requires minimal assumptions on the objective function. Since a bound of the same order is known to be valid for the unconstrained case, this leads to the conclusion that the presence of possibly nonlinear/nonconvex inequality/equality constraints is irrelevant for this bound to apply.
paper_title: On the complexity of finding first-order critical points in constrained nonlinear optimization
